Indications and doses

Alkalinisation of urine, Relief of discomfort in mild urinary-tract infections,

By mouth

  • For adults
    3 g every 2 hours until urinary pH exceeds 7, to be dissolved in water.

Maintenance of alkaline urine,

By mouth

  • For adults
    5–10 g daily, to be dissolved in water.

Chronic acidotic states such as uraemic acidosis or renal tubular acidosis,

By mouth

  • For adults
    4.8 g daily, (57 mmol each of Na+ and HCO3 –), higher doses may be required and should be adjusted according to response.

Severe metabolic acidosis,

By slow intravenous injection or by intravenous infusion

  • For adults
    Administer an amount appropriate to the body base deficit, to be given by slow intravenous injection of a strong solution (up to 8.4%), or by continuous intravenous infusion of a weaker solution (usually 1.26%).

Removal of ear wax (with 5% ear drop solution),

To the ear

  • For adults
    (consult product literature).
  • For children
    (consult product literature).

Advice when patient is pregnant

In adults

Use with caution in urinary conditions.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

In adults

In patients with fluid retention, avoid large amounts of sodium.

Advice regarding renal impairment

In adults

Avoid (except for specialised role in some forms of renal disease).

Contra indications

  • Salt restricted diet

Known side effects

Specific side effects

notKnown: dryness of the ear canal, alkalosis on prolonged use in adults, eructation in adults, fluid retention (in those at risk), hypokalaemia may be exacerbated, increase blood pressure, pulmonary oedema (in those at risk), fluid retention (in those at risk), hypokalaemia may be exacerbated, increase blood pressure, pulmonary oedema (in those at risk), alkalosis on prolonged use in adults, eructation in adults,

Directions for administration

With intravenous use in children

For peripheral infusion dilute 8.4% solution at least 1 in 10.

For central line infusion dilute 1 in 5 with Glucose 5% or 10% or Sodium Chloride 0.9%.

Extravasation can cause severe tissue damage.

With intravenous use in adults

For slow intravenous injection use a small volume of hypertonic solution (such as 50 mL of 8.4%).

For continuous intravenous infusion a weaker solution of 1.26% solution can be infused over 3–4 hours.

With oral use

Sodium bicarbonate may affect the stability or absorption of other drugs if administered at the same time. If possible, allow 1–2 hours before administering other drugs orally.

Advice for patients and carers

Patients or carers should be given advice on the administration of sodium bicarbonate oral medicines.

In children

Medicines for Children leaflet: Sodium bicarbonate for acidosis

www.medicinesforchildren.org.uk/sodium-bicarbonate-for-acidosis

Cautions regarding administration

  • : Avoid prolonged use in urinary conditions in adults
  • : cardiac disease in adults
  • : elderly in adults
  • : patients on sodium-restricted diet in adults
  • respiratory acidosis

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

With intravenous use

Plasma-pH and electrolytes should be monitored.

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Oral solutions of sodium bicarbonate are required occasionally; these are available from 'special-order' manufacturers or specialist importing companies; the strength of sodium bicarbonate should be stated on the prescription.

Prepared medicinal forms of SODIUM BICARBONATE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: solution for injection, oral suspension, oral solution, powder, capsule, liquid, mouthwash,
